header_summary:
Yuval Kogman highlights the importance of preventing clients from accumulating blind signatures in mixing services like Wasabi 1 to avoid disrupting the mixing process. The discussion also underscores the potential for observation attacks aimed at deanonymizing users, although such attacks are deemed implausible with the current archived client software versions. Moreover, concerns are raised about the possibility of servers covertly deanonymizing users by manipulating UTXO placements in mixing rounds, a subtle vulnerability that underscores the challenges in ensuring user privacy in cryptocurrency transactions. Ongoing discussions focus on mitigating history intersection attacks through measures like log scrubbing and deterministic shuffling of transactions ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAAQdECCq5n7zkRJboVwjLMWkGUP7-G2U7tK4Ekf5M9NqLypLQA@mail.gmail.com/T/#m67d35c282feb10ffc6980888dece47e68b7b95d4)).

Ariard delves into the concept of "punishable Eltoo" in multi-party settings, exploring its potential to enhance security and trustlessness in blockchain technologies. The discussion encompasses the challenges of achieving a purely trustless design in multi-party systems, emphasizing the scalability and feasibility across various applications. Significant attention is given to the CoinPool paper's ambitious goal and the difficulties in efficiently assigning blame among non-trusted parties in off-chain constructions, pointing towards the necessity for further research in scalable, secure, and trustless multi-party systems within the blockchain ecosystem ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/multi-party-eltoo-with-bounded-settlement/1364/3)).

McElrath proposes specific covenant-based solutions for managing transactions within a Bitcoin mining pool to ensure accurate and theft-proof payouts without custody. This alternative to the FROST federation aims to mitigate risks such as vulnerability to attacks and political complications in federation membership decisions. The discussion advocates for covenant-based alternatives that enforce strict transaction paths and outlines preliminary suggestions to ensure secure and accurate payouts in line with Bitcoin's decentralized ethos, highlighting the dynamic nature of payout adjustments and the importance of considering the 100 block coinbase maturity rule in crafting these covenant proposals ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/challenge-covenants-for-braidpool/1370)).

Sipa addresses the challenge of proving the optimality of a transaction subset $B$ based on fee rates, without considering interdependencies or topology. The discussion clarifies the uniqueness of $B$ by demonstrating that no two distinct subsets can satisfy the optimality property without contradiction. This analysis contributes to the understanding of transaction selection strategies in blockchain systems, emphasizing the importance of fee rates in determining the inclusion and exclusion of transactions in an optimal set ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/how-to-linearize-your-cluster/303/7)).

recent_posts.title: Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks
recent_posts.summary:
- Handling blind signatures in mixing services prevents accumulation for later use.
- Covert deanonymization through UTXO placement poses significant risks in mixing rounds.
- Despite efforts, concerns about user privacy due to log practices and intersection attacks remain.

recent_posts.title: Multi-Party Eltoo with bounded settlement
recent_posts.summary:
- "Punishable Eltoo" explores penalty mechanisms in blockchain for enhanced security and trustlessness.
- Challenges in multi-party system scalability and trustlessness are critical for blockchain advancement.
- Resources provide insights into overcoming scalability and security issues in blockchain multi-party systems.

recent_posts.title: Challenge: Covenants for Braidpool
recent_posts.summary:
- Covenant proposals aim to enhance Bitcoin mining pool security and payout accuracy.
- They offer an alternative to FROST federation, reducing custodial risks and political issues.
- The proposals include mechanisms for dynamic payout adjustments and theft prevention.

recent_posts.title: How to linearize your cluster
recent_posts.summary:
- The subset $B$ optimally includes transactions with the highest fee rates, excluding lower ones.
- A paradox arises when assuming two subsets, $B_1$ and $B_2$, both meet the optimal criteria.
- Equality of $B$ and $pot$ is proven through their construction from transactions arranged by fee rate.

active_posts.title: Trivial QC signatures with clean upgrade path
active_posts.summary:
- Quantum computing may threaten Bitcoin's EC encryption within twenty years, urging protocol upgrades.
- Hash-based signatures, especially SPHINCS/SPHINCS+, emerge as viable post-QC security solutions within Bitcoin.
- Leveraging taproot for post-QC security proposes soft-fork adaptability without immediate user action.

active_posts.title: Summary: Covenants Support - Bitcoin Wiki
active_posts.summary:
- Significant updates were added to the Bitcoin covenants wiki in late November 2024.
- Feedback from developers and podcast listeners has influenced the development of a dedicated use case page.
- A call to action was made for technical consensus on covenant implementation in the Bitcoin community.

active_posts.title: TRUC and P2A for CTV fee management
active_posts.summary:
- OP_CTV's fixed output/input tree eliminates dynamic fee adjustments via RBF.
- New v3 transactions enable fee bumps via CPFP, addressing OP_CTV's fee market sensitivity.
- Future explorations will address the broader implications of these developments on CTV transactions.

active_posts.title: Timewarp attack 600 second grace period
active_posts.summary:
- Matt Corallo proposes limiting `nTime` rolling in Bitcoin mining to enhance ASIC efficiency.
- Current testnet adjustments allow backward `nTime` adjustments up to 600 seconds to maintain network integrity.
- Discussions suggest expanding this to two hours, limiting potential timestamp exploits and ensuring blockchain security.

active_posts.title: CTV, APO, CAT activity on signet
active_posts.summary:
- BIPs 118, 119, and 347 introduce major scripting changes to Bitcoin on signet.
- APO enables more flexible transaction signing; CTV and CAT see varied experimental use.
- Observations highlight utilization patterns, including security and functionality enhancements in Bitcoin scripting.

active_posts.title: Fastest-possible PoW via Simple DAG
active_posts.summary:
- An advancement in Braidpool's algorithm achieves consensus without traditional metrics, focusing on DAG width.
- Targeting two parents per block optimizes consensus, with a unique difficulty adjustment algorithm aiding adaptability.
- The approach mirrors the Avalanche protocol, balancing efficiency, security, and decentralization in blockchain consensus.

today_in_history_posts.title: Bi-directional micropayment channels with CHECKLOCKTIMEVERIFY
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The proposed protocol employs reversible micropayment channels, enhancing transaction flexibility.
- It introduces a secure method for both parties to manage payments via P2SH addresses.
- The protocol streamlines reversals and closures, minimizing dependencies on CHECKLOCKTIME.

today_in_history_posts.title: Routing and explicit trust
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The paper questions terms "channel counterparty" and "clearinghouse", exploring associated risks and trust.
- It highlights trust requirements in level 2 protocols and the capping of risks by trusting counterparties.
- Discusses systemic risks and propagation of failures due to interconnected counterparty exposures.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin aims for 1 billion weekly users with 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks."- Increasing block size for scalability is impractical; solutions like Utreexo and OP_VAULT are explored.
- Networking off-chain entities with proper tools ensures regulatory compliance and auditability.
